The singular values of ''A'' are the square root of the eigenvalues of ''A<sup>T</sup>A''.

sols_html:
Given \(A=\begin{pmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 1& 0\\ 0&1 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(A^{^{T}}=\begin{pmatrix} 1 &1 &0 \\ 0&0 &1 \end{pmatrix}\) we calculate \(A^{T}A=\begin{pmatrix} 2 &0 \\ 0&1 \end{pmatrix}\), which has the eigenvalues 2 and 1. Hence, the singular values of A are \(\sqrt{2}\) and \(\displaystyle 1\).

Putting the singular values on the diagonal of \(\Sigma\) we find that \(\Sigma =\begin{pmatrix} \sqrt{2} &0 \\ 0&1 \\ 0&0 \end{pmatrix}.\)
